I appreciate one of the other answers, which pointed out that there are many varying definitions of faith. Here’s what I call “faith”. Faith is not just accepting whatever a “holy book” says just because that’s my religion’s holy book. Faith is not just believing something that there’s no evidence for. My faith is based upon evidence- logic, reason, science, observation, history, etc. Here’s a way I like to put it- I believe in God for the same reason I believe the wind is blowing when looking out my window. I cannot see the wind, smell the wind, taste the wind, or hear the wind (unless it’s crazy out there!!). Nor can I feel the wind from inside my house. But I can see the trees shaking, and I can see the leaves flying across the yard. While I cannot scientifically observe the wind itself, I -can- observe the evidences of it: through the effect that it has. While I have never scientifically observed God himself, I have scientifically observed the evidences of God and the effect He has had. That’s why I believe.I also believe in the divine inspiration of the Bible because of the mindblowing evidence to support such. Scientific foreknowledge, prophecies that have historically come true, logical consistency and singular focus even though written by many authors over thousands of years, and more. When it comes to the book itself, faith isn’t just accepting whatever it says. Faith involves belief based upon evidence, logical discernment of truth, and THEN trusting in the things that don’t make as much sense, because of the things which do. Then, faith involves a logical reaction to that belief- what should I do because of this? Here’s how I define “faith”, and it happens to be a definition that fits what the Bible (our “holy book”) describes as faith. Faith is belief, trust, and action, based upon critical thinking in response to logical truth and evidence. To use the words of the Bible itself, “faith is the substance of things hoped for, the evidence of things not seen.”

+JMJ+ No, not at all! Faith is a gift from God in your baptism. It has nothing to do with a book. from A Catholic Dictionary, edited by Donald Attwater, Second edition, revised 1957 Faith. i. The object of belief; the sum of the truths taught by the Catholic religion. ii. A theological virtue (Virtues, The Theological. Supernatural gifts enabling man to attain his final destiny, so called because they have God—the object of our faith, in whom we hope, whom we love—for their immediate object; three in number: faith, hope, charity.) by which our intellect is disposed to assent firmly to all the truths revealed by God, because of the infinite truth and wisdom of God who can neither deceive or be deceived. The words of St. Paul (Heb. xi, 1), Faith is “that which gives substance to our hopes, which convinces us of things we cannot see” make a convenient definition of faith, and all other definitions are a development of this. “If you would reduce the words to the form of a definition, you might say: Faith is a habit of the mind by which eternal life is begun in us, in that it makes the intellect assent to things which appear not . . . the fact that it is called evidence (argumentum) distinguishes faith from opinion, suspicion, and doubt, in which here is no firm adhesion of the intellect to anything; the fact that it is ‘of things which we cannot see,’ distinguishes it from knowledge and understanding, by which a thing becomes apparent. The fact that it ‘gives substance to our hopes’ distinguishes the virtue of faith from faith in common acceptance, which is not ordained to any hoped-for happiness” (St. Thomas, II-II, iv, 1). “Since faith rests upon infallible truth and the contrary of a truth can never be demonstrated, it is clear that the arguments brought against the faith cannot be strict demonstrations, but the difficulties that can be answered” (St. Thomas I, 1, 8c), or in the words of Cardinal Newman, “Ten thousand difficulties do not make one doubt.” iii. Justifying. Faith is necessary for justification, but it must be true faith and not merely the confidence which Luther depended upon: “If anyone say that justifying faith is nothing else than confidence in the divine mercy which remits sins on account of Christ . . . let him be anathema” (Council of Trent, sess. vi, can 12, de justificatione); “Go out all over the world and preach the gospel to the whole creation. He who believes and is baptized will be saved; he who refuses belief will be condemned” (Mark xvi, 15, 16). And for salivation this faith must be informed by charity.

Every worldview is a faith in this sense; for example, communism trusting in the writings of Marx, especially Communist Manifesto and Das Kapital. Hello, This is a fantastic question! First, I think that the answer depends on your own definition of ‘faith’. My definition of faith consists of ‘believing in something that cannot be definitively proven by science’. For example, I have faith in myself, and in psychic readings, and in the law of attraction. These things cannot be definitively proven, but yet they also don't come from a holy book. Religions tend to make their own definitions for vocabulary words that oftentimes don’t match up to more secular definitions, so your definition of ‘faith’ can be drastically different from another individual’s definition. Also, many people are spiritual but not religious, so they have faith in a higher power, but do not associate that higher power with any god from any religious belief system. I think what is interesting to explore is the difference between faith and belief. To me, these two terms are roughly synonymous with each other, and I use them more or less interchangeably, although other people may disagree. So, the question you’re asking really becomes, ‘what does faith mean to you?’ I hope this helps!

From the study, “The Faith of Jesus Christ”. God has elected that we must have faith as a determining factor as to whether or not we "please him" Few of the disputes and controversies debated within the Church are as important or as consequential as those embroiling faith. It is required of us to be pleasing to God, essential for salvation and its absence in anything constitutes sin. Romans 14:23 ...for whatsoever is not of faith is sin.For these reasons, it would seem that understanding what the Scriptures mean by it would be advisable. The definition of “faith” or rather the perceived definition is itself a stumbling block and has been for centuries. It is often added to and occasionally considered to be a mystical quality beyond man’s ability to have. Faith is a divine virtue that can only occur in the human breast by an act of divine grace Thomas Aquinas 1225-74Faith is the gift of God's grace; it is not merited, earned, nor self-created Emil Brunner—1899~1966But, what do the Scriptures have to say? As this is a word study it would be proper to begin by simply looking at the dictionary definition of faith. Most abridged dictionaries will give the two most common meanings. Faith: Confidence, reliance, trust; BeliefThat which is believed or the object of beliefThe two meanings simply look at faith from opposite ends. I have faith in this — This is my faithI have faith in Jesus Christ — I hold to the faith of Jesus ChristRevelation 14:12 Here is the patience of the saints: here are they that keep the commandments of God, and the faith of Jesus.“That keep...the faith of Jesus.” The fact that faith can be looked at from these two directions will be a very important concept to remember in studying this error. Two examples of it being used for the objects of belief is found in Galatians and 1 Timothy. Galatians 1:23 But they had heard only, That he which persecuted us in times past now preacheth the faith which once he destroyed.1 Timothy 3:9 Holding the mystery of the faith in a pure conscience.“The faith” in these verses stands for the corporate beliefs or objects of belief that Paul once persecuted but now preaches. He persecuted those who held faith in Jesus Christ, he persecuted “the faith of Jesus Christ,” thankfully, he now holds “the faith of Jesus Christ.” The biblical definition of faith is also to believe. Hebrews 11:6 But without faith it is impossible to please him: for he that cometh to God must believe that he is,...“Faith...must believe,” having the faith needed to please God begins with believing he is. Isaiah 43:10 Ye are my witnesses, saith the LORD, and my servant whom I have chosen: that ye may know and believe me, and understand that I am he: before me there was no God formed, neither shall there be after me.The Lord has always been attempting to get men to believe, put their faith, in him. Numbers 14:11 And the LORD said unto Moses, How long will this people provoke me? and how long will it be ere they believe me, for all the signs which I have showed among them?Deuteronomy 32:20 And he said, I will hide my face from them, I will see what their end shall be: for they are a very froward generation, children in whom is no faith.Faith is also defined in Romans as believing. Romans 4:3-5 For what saith the scripture? Abraham believed God, and it was counted unto him for righteousness. 4Now to him that worketh is the reward not reckoned of grace, but of debt. 5But to him that worketh not, but believeth on him that justifieth the ungodly, his faith is counted for righteousness.It is God who justifies the ungodly. Believing on him is defined in the above passage as exercising one’s own faith, “his faith is counted for righteousness.” Take note here that faith/belief is in contrast to works, “to him that worketh not, but believeth.” For greater detail read the whole study, “The Faith of Jesus Christ”.

I will answer this from the Bible perspective, which has been considered a holy book. Most people read the Bible for entertainment, or for scholarly work, or any other secular thing. The Bible was written, and should be believed in, according to what it was written for: correction, reproof, and instruction in righteousness (2 Timothy 3:16–17). When we believe in the Bible, we use it to get rid of our infirmities, namely the ones mentioned in Galatians 5:19–21, 1 Corinthians 6:9–10, Romans 1:28–32, etc. Having faith in God means to work according to his plan, because you hope and believe that it will to the destiny of all righteous ones: eternal life in a righteous world (Romans 8:24–25). Abraham’s faith wasn’t based on a book; after all, the Bible, or any Jewish writing, for that matter, hadn’t been done at that time. However, he still had faith, because he believed in the plan of God. God plays a role in this happening, as demonstrated in Acts 2:37 and Acts 16:14. God opens the heart to accept the gospel, and believe in it, meaning to live by its principles. It Pays to Fear God

Christian Faith requires four steps: Belief that God exists and communicates through the Bible;Obedience of God's commands as laid out in the Bible;Confession that we often fail to obey; andRepentance = changing our ways from sin to love.Of course, we all fail to varying degrees at each and every one of these steps: we doubt, we sin, we cover up, and we stubbornly refuse to change.
